Competitor
Overview
Overview of competitor software products represented at the 2013 NAB Show in Las Vegas.


Produced by: Jason Schmidt, UX Designer


Simon Eldridge provided a list of 12 companies to review on the main floors of the NAB show in order of importance. As an independent consultant, I visited each company's booth, watched product demos, took photos of software interfaces, asked general questions of sales staff and procured marketing brochures. In passing I also took note of a few products not on the list that stood out.
Snell: Momentum
Workflow Automation
Miranda (Belden)
On-demand Workflows
Elemental
Multiscreen Delivery
Tedial
Workflow Automation
Evertz
Playout and Asset Management
Aspera
File Transfer
Signiant
File Sharing / Transfer
Dalet
Asset Management
Telestream
Workflow Automation / Transcoding
NTT
Contribution Encoder
Ericcson
Everything Video
Cisco
End-to-End Video

 
Snell
Snell's pertinent product is Momentum — a "media factory" or workflow automation and media asset management system offering:

  • Cataloging
  • Editing
  • Transcoding
  • Delivery

Momentum's user interface model describes modules in the media flow process as "elements."

As a first element a customer would typically set up an "ingest." A second element might be a "catalog." A third could optionally be a "quality control." Each of these elements includes applicable settings and incorporates multiple sub-processes which can be customized for a customer's needs, making it a modular, flexible architecture. For the "edit" element Momentum interfaces with FCP, Premier and Avid. For the "transcode" element, it is compatible with industry standards (including, Rhozet, Agility, Flip Factory and ICR). Finally, the "delivery" element outputs to server, FTP and/or archive.

The Momentum UX presents a very literal metaphor carried to the UI as an editable flowchart. The metaphor provides a meta-perspective on workflow and a simple navigation scheme with points of entry to deeper configurations.

Snell marketing site


Snell at NAB

 


 


 
Miranda (a Belden company)
Miranda's "Channel-in-a-box" product, called ITX, provides a software solution that integrates with commodity hardware for managing all aspects of a broadcasting system. It boasts some key differentiators, including graphics creation and management directly in Adobe After Effects.

Miranda channel monitoring claims to accommodate the increasing complexities of metadata in broadcast feeds, e.g., ad insertion triggers and multiple languages. Their promise to their customers is less operators with higher quality and/or more channel feeds with the same number of operators.

The user interface on Miranda products is not visually elegant, but utilitarian.

Miranda also manufactures several other production and broadcast tools, like an audio monitoring tool, called Kaleido-solo, suited for production, post-production and broadcast.

Miranda marketing site


Miranda at NAB

 


 



 
Elemental
Elemental Technologies' stated mission is to provide solutions for multiscreen content delivery. The company's products are integrated hardware / software solutions.

The company offers a clear breakdown on its 6 unique products:

  • Elemental Live
  • Elemental Server
  • Elemental Stream
  • Elemental Conductor
  • Elemental Cloud
  • Core Technologies - Video Compression

Elemental Live is a live video processing and encoding system. It offers adaptive bit rate streams to new media platforms using Adobe Dynamic Streaming, Microsoft Smooth Streaming and Apple HTTP Live Streaming protocols.

Elemental Server is a file-based video processing and transcoding system. It formats multiscreen content for multiple devices, including iPhone, iPad, Android, Boxee, PS3 and set-top boxes.

Elemental Stream offers video processing for content customization. The tool customizes content downstream of the core encoding process. It claims to lower costs for delivery of multi-bit rate video across a CDN.

Elemental Conductor provides unified video management, i.e., system management. The system monitors two or more Elemental Live units with secure administration and monitoring of multiple encoding units through a web-based user interface.

Elemental Cloud offers GPU-accelerated transcoding in the cloud.

Relative to other companies in the space, Elemental appears unified and consistent across products and marketing. Product user interfaces are clean, and it's branding across software and hardware is memorably green.

Elemental marketing site


Elemental at NAB

 


 



 
Tedial
Tedial offers workflow optimization and media asset management as software solutions to control 3rd-party hardware.

It's products are as follows:

  • AST
  • Tarsys
  • Capture
  • MPM
  • Ficus
  • Media Amigo
  • Non-broadcast
  • SaaS

AST is Tedial's hierarchical storage Management solution with unlimited distributed storage and specifically designed to integrate with its Tarsys product.

Tarsys is their media asset management system. While its focus is video, non-video files are also supported. Tarsys also includes rights management which can be customized to business rules and a database systme customizable for a broadcaster's unique data model. Tarsys integrates with Final Cut Pro giving editors direct browse and retrieve access to Tarsys from their FCP workstations.

Capture is Tedial's acquisition tool which takes video and audio from any source and converts it to any other.

MPM handles workflow automation. MPM makes media and metadata flow freely between the 3rd-party systems that are often incompatible.

Ficus is a business process management tool. It helps organize the way people work together in a broadcast facility.

Media Amigo is Tedial's cloud management product offering interchange of content among users and systems geographically dispersed.

Non-broadcast refers to tools from Tedial that are repurposed for companies not specifically in broadcast, including companies that need to manage a large number of assets.

SaaS is Tedial's solution for companies that cannot afford a state-of-the-art content management system or don't have the space for one. These customers can outsource Tedial technology harnessing the technology remotely.

Tedial's user interfaces appear technology-driven, rather than human-focused. Notably, the workflow visualizations are reminiscent of schematics for electronics production. The Web-based tools, however, appear well-organized with standard navigation and intuitive access to system components.

Tedial marketing site


Tedial at NAB

 



 
Evertz
Evertz offers a wide range of products for the broadcast industry, including for:

  • Live production
  • Multi-channel playout
  • Asset management
  • Storage
  • IPTV
  • Multi-screen delivery
  • Video transport
  • Video on-demand
  • Pro A/V solutions

The products are sold as bundled hardware and software. Overall, the product line is extensive and difficult for a newcomer to grasp. The user interface design of its software products, as seen below, appears designed by and for engineers as opposed to average people with less skills.

Evertz marketing site


Evertz at NAB

 


 



 
Aspera
Aspera is devoted to high-speed file transport.

The company offers a patented technology called FASP™ that "leverages existing WAN infrastructure and commodity hardware to achieve speeds that are up to hundreds of times faster than FTP and HTTP."

Aspera has elegant, attractive global branding on par with consumer brands. While it's web-based and desktop software UIs are simple and functional, the visual aspects of the brand do not carry through well. The usecases for file transport are much simpler than the myriad features required in a broadcast operation, so Aspera's UIs appear to provide intuitive usability, and do not suffer from excessive complexity. However, the large number of products families (~17) seem unnecessary for such a straightforward mission.

Aspera marketing site


Aspera at NAB

 


 



 
Signiant
Signiant appears to be a direct competitor to Aspera in the market for high-speed file transport.

The company offers at least three primary products:

  • Media Shuttle™
  • Media Exchange
  • Manager+Agents

Media Shuttle™ is a subscription-based service offering both standard and enterprise editions. It promises to be an FTP replacement.

Media Exchange focuses on person to system and system to person file transfer for "secure, unattended file delivery in a private cloud solution."

Manager+Agents offers system to system file movement with workflow automation. It includes automated batch file transfer, processing workflow (Virus, QC, Transcode, etc.)and cloud storage "on-ramp"

Signiant's provides Web-based, desktop and mobile apps for its products. The UIs are simple, basic and offer custom logo branding. However, the apps' look-and-feel are inconsistent, in fact substantially different, across the different mediums. Signiant marketing site


Signiant at NAB

 


 



 
Dalet
Dalet's focus is media asset management (MAM). It's flagship product Galaxy is the company's latest upgrade (released at the NAB Show in 2012) of its legacy MAM. Galaxy also incorporates many aspects of business process management (BPM) to manage teams in a product environment. A "Designer Tool" allows customers to model their workflow graphically and customize performance indicators.

The Galaxy interface on, for instance, the "Task Manager" appears functional but is not well-designed visually, making poor use of positive and negative space and old-school styling. As with many such UIs, the result is unnecessary mental fatigue.

Dalet also offers other products, including a "multimedia editor" called One Cut which appears to be a copy of Final Cut Pro integrated with Dalet's MAM.

Dalet marketing site


Dalet at NAB

 


 



 
Telestream
Telestream's Vantage 5.0 offers a suite of products to fuel file transcoding for multiscreen delivery. It offer integrated hardware and software solutions. Its products can be used standalone or clustered using Vantage Array with its System Management product. Telestream's product families are listed below:

  • Transcode / Transcode Pro
  • Transcode Multiscreen
  • Transcode IPTV and Cable VOD
  • Workflow
  • System Management
  • Lightspeed Server

The company has some notably differentiators in its products, like integration with 3rd-party solutions, including Aspera for file transport.

Telestream also offers a handful of low-cost desktop apps and browser plugins, including a video player called Flip Player and ScreenFlow. Having used ScreenFlow for the desktop extensively, it is hands-down the best screencast creation app on the market with intelligent tools, simple and elegant UI and laser focused UX – a near perfect balance of the right number of features for the job without too many edit features to encumber the primary usecase.

Telestream marketing site


Telestream at NAB


 
NTT Electronics
NTT Electronics offers a range of products, including 10 rack-based hardware encoders and 13 modular chips for encoding across broadcast and consumer application.

The products appear to focus on utilitarian hardware for input / output speed and quality with little focus on UX/UI for software.

NTT marketing site


NTT at NAB


 
Ericcson
Ericcson's television and media management solutions include:

  • Multiscreen TV
  • Media Delivery Network
  • Ad Orchestrator

Multiscreen TV is "a complete end-to-end ecosystem from content acquisition, to content preparation, distribution, and state-of-the-art consumer experience." Unlike most other companies, Ericcson provides a client framework, SDK and portals to help OTT providers engage consumers, as well as provide the infrastructure to power the entire process. As of yet, I have been unable to evaluate the user experience potential of their consumer SDK..

Media Delivery Network is Ericcson's CDN boasting "a unique, single platform approach". Several other CDNs provide similar offerings, including BitGravity, Akamai and arguable Amazon Web Services.

Ad Orchestrator provides advertisers and agencies tools "to book, plan, deliver and monitor mobile advertising campaign across multiple channels." It claims to connect its customers with the media agencies who are buying the advertising space and creating campaigns. Generally, the product aims to broker partner publishers’ inventories.

Ericcson's global branding is creative and clearly the product of a branding agency partnership, while it's product UIs appear disconnected and inconsistent with the company look-and-feel.

Ericcson marketing site


Ericcson at NAB

 

 



 
Cisco
Cisco's video efforts are significant, extending from infrastructure to consumer. The NAB Show presented a few key product demos:

  • Videoscape Unity
  • Videoscape Cloud
  • Multiscreen Gateways

Videoscape Unity describes Cisco's end-to-end service to deliver video broadcast and user interactions to consumers.

Videoscape Cloud includes: Cisco Media Processor offering Adaptive Bit Rate (ABR) streaming, Transcode Manager for workflow management of file preparation, Videoscape Media Suite offering features to manage, publish, and monetize video content to multiple screens.

Multiscreen Gateways decode, and then distribute IP video, hybrid, or digital video broadcasting (DVB) and Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM)-based live, on-demand, online, and recorded video content services to other devices. Cisco Videoscape Multiscreen Gateways are targeted for service providers.

Cisco's marketing is visually appealing, but the presentation of its product line lacks logical connectedness, and the value proposition for each product is broad rather than deep. They do, however, offer some fresh visual and interaction models in their consumer products and reasonable organization in their management interfaces. Their successes derive from smart interaction designers, while their failures stem from poor understanding of UX by management, poor processes for decision-making and frequent pivots (or "re-orgs") within the organization.

Videoscape Unity
Videoscape Cloud
Multiscreen Gateway


Cisco at NAB
